												While going through the tutorial I really felt like this was a god aweful game... but only until I finished the tutorial and got into the actual game.I have played Deus Ex: Human Revolution so I knew what to expect and had high expectations, even though I knew this was a port of a mobile game. While it isn't as realized or complex as Human Revolution, I had fun the 5-6 hours it took me to get through it.While there are no micro transactions in the PC version of the game, you can still feel how the item shop was designed to give people the opportunity to spend real money on the game whenever they found themselves in a sticky situation - you can buy anything, ANYTHING that is available in the game on the fly, but it costs in-game currency in the PC port so you obviously can't be loaded with gear from the get-go.I give Deus Ex: The Fall 6/10 and I find the 2 Euro I spent on it was worth it (got it at reduced price - I probably won't recommend it at its full price).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												For the price of $2 during a sale, this is probably one of the better games you'll be able to buy.The amount of time I've played for is the amount of time it took me to get through the entire core campaign, neglecting all side missions (and there are a few of those). So, just take that into account. But for what it is, Deus Ex: HR Lite Edition, it's okay. Not phenomenal, but I had an itch for more Deus Ex: HR and didn't want to reinstall that game, so this little diversion did the job just fine. Something funny worth mentioning is that graphically, this game is on par with Human Revolution. That's a testament to both the evolution of mobile gaming graphics and how underbaked HR was. Not to mention that 300+ fps with maxed anti-aliasing is always nice. So, to reiterate, if you can snag it for $2 during a Square Enix sale like I did and are CRAVING more HR gameplay, get it. For any other situation, disregard The Fall.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												I wish I could say this game was another fine Deus Ex experience that upheld the reputation built by the games that preceded it, but I cannot.  While it does have a sort of similar flavor to Deus Ex: Human Revolution in terms of aesthetics and story, it is badly hampered by the limitations kept from the iOS it was originally designed for.  Also, in just under two hours, I've experienced two game-breaking bugs, one of which involved falling through the floor for several thousand meters and dying.  I know it's called Deus Ex: The Fall, but come on now.  I had to do that whole level over because of some debugging that was not only sub-par, but outright bad.  At least the amount of content that exists in a level is small enough that this didn't set me back all that much.Overall, a neat story wrapped in a bug-laden, ugly, poorly-adapted package.  If they fixed the bugs, I could almost look past the mediocre graphics, lack of a jump mechanic, and somewhat sluggish menu response, and call it worth five bucks, but as it is, I'm going to go ahead and advise you to stay away.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												 I played Human Revolution and I loved it. i beat that game 3 times in the pursuit of the pacifist achiement which never wanted to trigger (appently a crossbolt to the head was considered lethal :p) Okay lets talk Deus ex: Fall.  pro:  1.new aug that allows for two bars to be recharged that something the first lacked ( i have gotten the chanse to see directors cut difference either) 2. the quickslot tabs were really nice make swtiching for what i need so much easiernow I am going to start to nit pick some of these complains might not be to major but they are things that were revomed and I misscons: 1. Length 2.5 hours for $10? Yeah relly short for being the the first part I recommend wating till it goes on sale I still feel a little shortchanged paying $5 ther e is not much to do and belive you me I the kind of person who goes away from the objective to find the loot first. 2. odd take downs. Human Revolution had a great system when it comes to take downs in that where you took out your enemy made sense. In the fall I frecquntly find my self being launched 5 to 10 feet from where i initiated it and alerting other guards speaking of which.... 3. the AI and NPC: in human revolution mass panic took place the moment you took a guard in puplic in the fall these people Really could'nt give a ****. One NPC evwen said to me she was'nt paid enough for this crap. It really suspends the disbelief. 4. Disappering guards : I get this is supped to make thing easier guys but when I take a guard it seems really odd just having him vanish without a trace. In human reolution it make sense you had to hid ethe bodyies. ALso I had nurerous occurences of guards just going though walls  when I killed them. 5. Dialogue drops: at random points I have the voice acting just drop out, really odd but a simple bugs fix if they can find it. 6; infinite inventory and on hand store: i get these were mostly implemented to make things easier but I kinda of enjoyed managing my inventory in human revolution it felt real ansd seniblr that i couldnt cary 10 weapons at once. 7: minimizing of non leathals: I was saddened not to see the tranc rifle, gas crossbow ( the one they had was supernerfed), gas mines I loved those things. Also it semed that the stun gun range was nerfed by a about 5 ft as well for no good reason. 8: trckng aug removal: I loved that aug make stealing so much easier plus the ability to track invisble targets who would't miss it. 9: meh graphic. Now I may be crazy but I felt like the fall was a little less preety than human revolution. not enought to detract me but still it felt odd. Like I siad earlier this game is not worht the full price. If you were a fan of human revolutiion it a decent pickup, but wait for a sale. If you never played human revolution play that first then decide on this .

Posted: July 9, 2014
												I decided to recommend this game because there are already so many negative reviews out there, and I feel like the game is being underrated. But the fact is I wouldn't recommend this game to everyone, only if you fulfil the following criteria:1.	You liked Deus Ex: Human Revolution2.	The above made you go out and buy the book Deus Ex: Icarus effect3.	You liked the bookThe reason for this is that the game focuses on Benjamin Saxon, one of the main characters in the book, and it’s really cool to play him. The story takes place right after the end of the Icarus effect and it’s quite true to the events that take place there, there are even some recreations of the events in the book (I won’t get into details so there are no spoilers), and the dialogs are pretty much untouched from what you’ve read in the book. All of this makes for a good overall experience when playing the game, because you get to know what happens after the end of the book, and the story is very solid.The thing is that that’s pretty much it… The graphics are indeed horrible, the mouse look doesn’t work at 100% (the vertical axis his way less sensitive than the horizontal axis), you can’t change the controls (although for me that wasn’t really a problem). As for the audio issues, I didn’t come across anything. If you play the game with a headset, you should be fine.This being said, I’ll go on the L.I.M.B here and dare to say that gameplay wise, there are even some small improvements compared to HR. There are some cool new augs like the stealth dash and the body armor is no longer a passive aug. In HR this made the body armor a must get upgrade, because the result was that it made the game easier without any management. In The Fall, you have to manage when to activate it (which consumes energy) and when it activates it creates a glow around Saxon and you see a meter that tells you how much armor you have left and it drops when you take damage.There’s been some talk about the game ending in a cliff hanger but I don’t think that’s the case. The story isn’t finished, that’s obvious, but it wraps things up in that specific mission scenario. If part 2 ever comes out (which looks very unlikely, considering how things are going in Square Enix), I’ll want to play it, even if it’s flawed like the first one because for me the story is worth it and the flaws don’t make the game unplayable.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												I recommend it with some conditions. It's not a very good game, but I still found enough fun to be worth my time. If you consider this a higher quality fan mod (which is about the level of quality to expect here, not that it is an actual fan mod), there is some fun to be had here. Obviously, expecting this to be comparable to Human Revolutions or even the original Deus Ex will only result in dissapointment. VOICE ACTINGThe voice acting is pretty bad, but a lot better than I've seen from some fan mods that have tried to do voice acting.  The dialogue options are extremely limited, with very few opportunities for it to make a difference.STORYIt's ok and it keeps the pace going. GAMEPLAYA lot of areas are streamlined, probably primarily to do it being originally a mobile game. No jumping, which I disliked, but I can see why one might cut that here. It gives the designers a lot more control over where a player can go in the game without having to design additional ways to block player movement to account for jumping. This also focuses the type of gameplay they are offering, allowing multiple ways through environments. STEALTHI liked that full stealth options were available, as well as guns ablazing. HACKINGMuch easier than in Human Revolutions, but plenty of things to hack and a few good opportunities to turn robots and turrets against your enemies. GOODSI noticed a ton of weapons available for purchase... though I never bought any. The store might be too easy to access, but it gave a lot more options than typically can be found. Everything is probably too plentiful in the game. LEVELINGLeveling up was really quick, which was good since the game was short.ONE SAVE + BUGSI hate single save options. Just make sure when you save, nothing screwy is happening, though I found only a couple bugs during my playthrough.FINAL THOUGHTSIf anything, the game is too easy, but I still found it fun and I'm interested in seeing where things might go next, if they still planned on making another one. It's a nice diversion, as long as you don't expect much from it. Buy it on sale, if interested, and you should be good.

												I wont get into troubles, issues and bugs; yes, Deus Ex: The Fall has plenty of bugs and some annoying issues.... my personal favorite is the lack of audio from some npcs, then the hero, then music, then magical return of audio. But no i wont tell you is buggy, because, nowadays is a miracle if a game isnt buggy at all.... maybe i just gave up on this issue.About the storyline and gameplay, which in my opinion is what makes Deus Ex... well Deus Ex. Let me tell you, the gameplay resembles the original Deus Ex, combat is fair, the game requires you to use both sides of your brain, the hack mini game is really fun. Overall I liked its gameplay. At first I was annoyed about the weapon-praxis store inside the game, seems out of place somehow, but i guess it is because you want the player focus on the story and have fun blasting things around...But here is the real issue... i can understand bugs, i do not care about the overpowering store and easy achievable augs, the game could be in 2D-8bit for all i care.... BUT "TO BE CONTINUED!?!"  only after one fragging chapter!!! now that is something i cannot abide, specially after such a beautiful initial movie. It shows absolutely mediocrity and a huge lack of respect for players, which like me, play for the storyline. If you like a cliffhanger short story, buggy as hell, with a beautiful setting in a dystopian Panama city... go ahead, DE: "The Fall" is your game.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												I am a fan of Deus Ex ever since the first one came out. The second version Invisible War was awful, Human Revolution took back the lost ground. Now we have The Fall and on the first run it's look easily as good as HR. However I am experiencing a bug that make the game unplayable. It starts out just fine, but if you Quit and Reload the Sound Effects disappear, as well as speech - so you NEED to have the captions show up or you won't know what's going on, then other times the caption window fly by so fast you can't read them, and if there is a character speaking when this happens their speech is cut off. While the music is playing you don't get any sound effects, they return after the music loop finishes, and disappear again when it restarts. You cannot turn the music off, you can only turn it all the way down. That means it is still looping and causing the sound effects to stop. There's obviously some channel overlap going on as my Sound Card is easily able to put out multiple channels over multiple devices - through Dolby 5.1 speakers as well as a Dolby 7.1 surround headphones at the same time. That said there is a work around for the sound problem all you have to do is set your sound card to Stereo and the problem is solved. It doesn't look like Square Enix is interested in providing a fix. So if you can handle that, you can play the game just fine.

												The biggest thing that gets this game is that: The user interface is far less user-friendly and far more obstructive of gameplay as compared to its' predecessor Deus Ex: Human Revolution. The rest of this review is rambling into why and then a snobby joshing remark.After playing Deus Ex: Human Revolution and its' expansion, this game is disgustingly bad gameplay wise... they force a clunky tutorial upon you that utilizesa  robotic voice and provides a clubky interface... you now buy weapons and ammo on the fly... and it forces you to silence your assult rifle...You have to scroll through slots to drink beer, use painkillers... and even your abilities (such as stealth). This game is a huge disappointment visually as well... I got used to the beautiful game of Deus Ex: Human Revolution...There are many holes in walls that 1 can just simply stand up within too... I did not give the game long, but there are way better things to play, such as Deus Ex: Human Revolution again.If you love this series you’ll probably enjoy this game, and I probably will get around to playing it eventually… but it has no need to be expedited to the top of ones play list and is probably worth the $2.50 I paid for it… although if I had to do it over again I’d wait for it to be $10… although I am a cheap gamer (I wait for decent sales).I usually do not review a game if I am indifferent towards it or dislike it... and even then I at times rate up a game and state it's shortcomings etc. but this game simply had too many downfalls that it is indeed properly named Deus Ex: THE FALL (well below ones expectations). In short this game was a considerable step back in gameplay quality in all reguards from a game that came sooner in the series.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Ignore the metascore.  This game is no 46.  It is no 80, either, though.The biggest issue with The Fall is that it is a bad port, not necessarily a bad GAME.  You have no options to customise controls, menu clicking is annoyingly unresponsive, and leaving cover will sometimes go back to first person looking up at the sky for no reason as a default as a few gameplay flaws which were not issues on mobile.  Issues one and two did not exist because of the nature of touchscreens, and issue three never happened to me on mobile, either.  This game was not designed with PC in mind, and being hastily ported to it during Square-Enix's ♥♥♥♥♥torm politics and restructuring which began in 2012 and persists to this day was just a cash grab when it should have been delayed until it played like Deus Ex:  Human Revolution when on PC.With that being said, ten years ago this game would have been called by many players as fantastic because games were more mediocre in general (please do not bother to name rare, specific games from that era which you like as a retort since it probably not represent the shovelware climate).  In 2014, however, better quality overall is increasingly demanded by players when back then gamers were not as vocal as a whole--thank both the Internet and gaming becoming far more mainstream since the early 2000s in the west--and this is just NOT a great game by today's standards.It is, however, a definitive DE:HR sidestory experience, and it is very good in that right.  It looks, sounds, and feels like a gaiden of DE:HR and the story is great.  If you really enjoyed DE:HR or the DE series since the first like I did what with this being my favourite game series, you WILL enjoy this for about 10 or so hours.  Then, it ends, because SE decided to make it episodic content where it can charge you piecemeal for subsequent chapters.  The caveat to its piecemeal design is because the game's reception was so poor, I am largely certain that no new chapters will ever be released.  If they are, it will be more hurried content with much cut for time and budget constraints, à la the Xenosaga trilogy.The problem is not the game as much as it is how SE handled it, although the game does have its problems.  This review is simply to state that it is NOT deserving of the low 46 metascore just as sooooo many 90+ games are not even close to as deserving those high numbers...this is something that you can blame on the pay-for-scores game "journalism" paradigm of today.  Buy it on sale for $5 or less; this game sat on my Steam wishlist from its PC release date until it was $5, and I cannot recommend paying more for it even though I DO recommend playing it if you enjoy DE games.Oh, and for god's sake, if the PS2-era character models for this mobile game is the defining flaw in what makes this a "bad" game to you, you have no business critiquing any game whatsoever, let alone attempting to appreciate the DE series' level of depth and subtext beneath what are not-awful visuals.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												I'm not opposed to the idea behind it, a mini-series that focuses on side-characters from the novel; a sort of microcosm of Deus Ex HR's gameplay in an episodic format. The execution of this idea in The Fall leaves much to be desired, partially due to problems with the game itself, but mostly due to the pains of being an obviously rushed port.To the devs' credit, it does hit some HR beats. You have a hub location (Panama City Slums/Boardwalk/Downtown), with plenty of storage units and gates to hack, a few side-quests (though they are gated by story progress), buildings with hackable doors and safes, man-sized vent systems to serve as alternate paths, upgrade points and PRAXIS kits, stealth takedowns, tons of goodies lying around in or on trashcans/desks/safes, and the persuasion system returns at certain points (and thankfully, the CASIE mod is not an insta-win button this time, just a way to score some extra items/info).And that leads us to the rub. Imagine, for a moment, if there was a painting you enjoyed so much that you commissioned a different artist to make a painting with a similar style and feeling, with one stipulation: the artist can never look at the original painting, they can only use your written description. Even if the finished painting resembles the original painting's style from a distance, when placed upon closer inspection, several flaws will surface.There are a variety of upgradable weapons, but the balance feels weird (e.g. headshots from the base pistol are not one-hit kills, which means that the silenced pistol isn't a useful stealth weapon until you apply a damage upgrade). You can still choose to go in stealthily or burst in guns blazing, but the small area sizes with few enemies makes the faster Rambo option much more viable (the Pacifist achievement is bugged, as it unlocks even if you kill people in the campaign). Plus, the AI is as dumb as a doorstop; civilians don't react if you takedown a guard right in front of them; in a firefight, guards will either stay in place or walk towards your position. There are computers to hack, but almost all of them are unlock codes for doors and safes; outside of two memorable e-mails (one being from a certain person in the novel, and another referencing FF27), it's a wasted opportunity for world-building.The story starts off somewhat interesting (Ben's flashback to his last mission with the Tyrants), then it devolves into what's essentially busywork, as Ben Saxon puts the conspiracy-fighting on hold to go to Panama City and try to find a source of Neuropozyne for himself and Anna Kelso. Naturally, he stumbles onto a conspiracy (because conspiracies are as common as Starbucks in the world of Deus Ex). Things do get somewhat interesting again due to a twist. Unfortunately, the game doesn't go into much effort to build the characters of Ben/Anna/Janus, nor does it provide much of a look at the Tyrants, with the exception of Jaron Namir. It also doesn't give much background on these characters outside of a rough outline established by a few audio logs; leaving much of their origins in the novel.If it were just those problems, I'd probably excuse it, but as I said before, a bevy of porting problems indicate that this was a rushed port. The UI is largely the same as the mobile version, and while I can see how it would have worked on a touchscreen, it's clunky and unintuitive with a mouse and keyboard. Switching items/grenades/weapons are mainly accomplished by holding their designated key and picking the desired item with the mouse. It pauses the game, but it feels like an unnecessary step. I guess you can use the number bar, but, unlike HR, there's no constant reminder of what each number activates. That's a problem throughout the whole UI: It doesn't generally show key or button prompts, just action prompts. You might end up checking the key bindings infographic quite often. Then there's the graphics, which weren't scaled up for the PC release, so you'll frequently notice blurry textures, simple geometry, and many low-res character models. The only character models that are detailed decently enough are the Belltower guards, the Riot Cops, and the characters that are important to the storyline (though Ben has a dead-eyed stare when his shades aren't on). Despite the low-res graphics, I still experienced some framerate drops at random times.There are a few other notable problems with the port; a few bugs (there's a bundle of four barrels in the drug den with a Pocket Secretary on it, I'd fall through the floor and die if I took cover on it and grabbed the PS), only one save slot (saved at area changes and quick saves; I could feasibly see someone saving in an unwinnable position), the single-mouse-button shooting controls (on the crossbow, holding LMB will aim down the scope; on other weapons, it'll just fire multiple times). Perhaps the most annoying thing is when two objects are very close to each other (e.g. credits in a netphone slot); you have your crosshair on one object (the credits) and the game activates the other object (the netphone) when you hit the use key, until you find the correct position/angle to stand at.Oh, and as for that buggered-up recoil that you've probably seen in gifs, they've fixed that problem. Now the recoil is just a slight screen shake; the difference is immediately obvious as soon as you fire a gun.It's a sideways-thumb kind of game (leaning heavily towards thumbs down due to the rushed-port problems); not that good, but not so terrible that I'd want to actively warn people off of it. If you got into the Humble Bundle early (back when the BTA was $5-6), then it might be worth upgrading to check it out. Not so much at the current BTA price unless HB adds some big bonuses on Tuesday.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												As an avid fan of DX:HR, quite honestly one of my favorite games ever played, I had high hopes for DX: The Fall. Profound disappointment cannot even begin to sum up my reaction. Every element of immersion, control, and user based choices from HR has been stripped down to an embarassing minimum.  Plot elements, instead of verging on that of a thriller, more resemble the Time Crisis games at aracades (Look bad guy! Bad guy is bad! Shoot bad guy!)Created for tablets, the controls lack that of a true gaming experience.  Point and click objectives, useless aiming (or lack there of) mechanics, and choppy cover mechanics are just a slap in the face.For a tablet, the graphics are great.  For a PC game, the graphics resemble a PS2 shooter; no details, slapped together polys, and generic scenary.  The sounds were entertaining at least.You'll see some familiar faces here, but not really any you will develop a connection to.If this was a $0.99 tablet game, I'd be fine with it. But for $10.00, save your money and put it towards the Director's cut of DX:HR.tl;dr - If it's free, go ahead. If not, just play DX:HR and pretend this doesn't exist.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												I decided to recommend this game because there are already so many negative reviews out there, and I feel like the game is being underrated. But the fact is I wouldn't recommend this game to everyone, only if you fulfil the following criteria:1.	You liked Deus Ex: Human Revolution2.	The above made you go out and buy the book Deus Ex: Icarus effect3.	You liked the bookThe reason for this is that the game focuses on Benjamin Saxon, one of the main characters in the book, and it’s really cool to play him. The story takes place right after the end of the Icarus effect and it’s quite true to the events that take place there, there are even some recreations of the events in the book (I won’t get into details so there are no spoilers), and the dialogs are pretty much untouched from what you’ve read in the book. All of this makes for a good overall experience when playing the game, because you get to know what happens after the end of the book, and the story is very solid.The thing is that that’s pretty much it… The graphics are indeed horrible, the mouse look doesn’t work at 100% (the vertical axis his way less sensitive than the horizontal axis), you can’t change the controls (although for me that wasn’t really a problem). As for the audio issues, I didn’t come across anything. If you play the game with a headset, you should be fine.This being said, I’ll go on the L.I.M.B here and dare to say that gameplay wise, there are even some small improvements compared to HR. There are some cool new augs like the stealth dash and the body armor is no longer a passive aug. In HR this made the body armor a must get upgrade, because the result was that it made the game easier without any management. In The Fall, you have to manage when to activate it (which consumes energy) and when it activates it creates a glow around Saxon and you see a meter that tells you how much armor you have left and it drops when you take damage.There’s been some talk about the game ending in a cliff hanger but I don’t think that’s the case. The story isn’t finished, that’s obvious, but it wraps things up in that specific mission scenario. If part 2 ever comes out (which looks very unlikely, considering how things are going in Square Enix), I’ll want to play it, even if it’s flawed like the first one because for me the story is worth it and the flaws don’t make the game unplayable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												A Decent Deus Ex Game Held Back by a Terrible PC PortDeus Ex: The Fall is a decent Deus Ex game, if you can look beyond the terribel PC port, poor graphics and and abysmal shooting mechanics, then you'll find an enjoyable but short singleplayer campaign. I clocked in around 6.8 hours for my first run, but I was looking for loot and doing sidequests, so if you rush its probably more like 3 hours. It's clear that the developers didn't bother to adapt the Ipad game to PC.What the Game Does WrongThe biggest problem with the game is the shooting, its terrible, if you're shooting something apart from the assault rifle your FOV will move up and down, creating a disorienting screen shake effect, this is most noticeable with the shotgun which could make someone nautious  with repeated use. Scoped weapons are incredibly awkard to use too, instead of holding right mouse or mousewheel to look down your scope and  pressing left mouse to shoot, you hold left mouse to look down scope and release to shoot, its so akward that I never used a scoped weapon outside of the tutorial. There is no aim down sights, the gunplay feels flacid and unsatisfying.Also in gunfights the AI is terrible, if they aren't standing in the open shooting at you, they are taking cover at the wrong wall leaving them exposed to you. All these issues means make  you want to avoid gunplay because of the screen effect and the akwardness of the scoped weapons, and poor AI. Aside from the gunplay, gameplay dumbed down for Ipad is left unchanged, smaller leves, there is no jump buttion, only jumping over predetermined locations, no sprint, you cannot move objects around, bodies dissapear into particles so you can't move bodies, there is no inventory screen instead there is a shop/inventory screen where you can buy anything at any time  so you can buy items in the middle of a firefight.The graphics and PC port are also terrible, there is limited pc options and the port lacks many important essentials. For example there are no save slots, only one save slot that is used for autosave, thankfully there is quicksave which works just fine. The graphics are poor to, textures are very poor quality for 2014, animations are awkward, especially the taking cover animation.What the Game Does WellWhile the game's levels are alot smaller compared to Human Revolution, they are open-ended enough to be fun to sneak around, the hub area is also good theres quite a bit of loot hidded, althought the lack of jump means its not as fun as Human Revolution's hubs. There's about 6 sidequests to do, all of them add some secondary objectives to your main missions.Overall the sneaking is well executed too, I never noticed moments where I felt I should have been seen but wasn't or vice versa, and the routes you go to avoid guards a fun to find. I played through the game ghost style and there wasn't any area outside the tutorial where I felt the game was pushing me towards combat. Augmentations are largely unscathed, they basically got all the useful augmentations from Human Revolution and put them in there's a new augmentation called 'stealth run' but it feels akward using it on PC, its something was clearly designed for Ipad.Story is interesting, the presmise is that there's a new alternative to Neuropozine, however it looks like there's something suspicious with the drug. Unfortunately there's no real resolution to this plot as it ends on a cliffhanger, as there's meant to be an episode 2, but I won't hold my breath for episode 2. The voice acting is not great, it ranges from horrendous to okay. ReccomendationIf you play Deus Ex for its shooting, then you should avoid this game, however if you play for the stealth gameplay then the you will probably enjoy the game, the stealth is well executed and there's always a way to complete the ojectives stealthily.If you do play Deus Ex for the stealth, I would reccomend picking up the game during a sale, I got my copy for $3 and I felt I got my money's worth.  If you're new to the Deus Ex series I'd reccomend you get the original or Human Revolution Director's Cut instead of this, they have much better mechanics and depth compared to this game. I think only hardcore Deus Ex  fans will be willing to overlook the poor PC port, graphics and design decisions in this game.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												The Fall isn't a game that I would recommend for a Deus Ex experience.Pros:For a mobile game it does have some good backgroundsSaxon who is the player character has some potential in terms of story and character building.I actually liked the plane level and the turntable was a nice feature.Cons:Gameplay tries but fails to emulate Deus Ex HRThe story didn't really catch my attention and I often skipped quite a bit of the dialogue. I do think that think that there is a story there but it’s just presented in such a bland way that you just switch offOh and the weapon animations are horribleThe first (tutorial) mission felt really quite bland which is a shame considering the venue was Moscow which could have been interesting.It's unfinished. To be frank there's a whole list of other things that have gone wrong with this game which has already been pointed out.And if I was asked to develop a game for mobile platforms and PC then I would not have chosen an FPS format.In short: Do not purchase this game and definitely not at full price although I purchased this as part of a bundle.Recommendations:I would turn this into a top down RPG instead although this may have to sacrifice some Deus Ex features but you could end up with much better gameplay and graphics which doesn't look quite so wanting and still be able to have acceptable looking custcenes.Get rid of the purchase menu; I don't know what they were thinking by including that.Also the environments need to be better developed. The Panama level just felt like a copy and paste of the Detroit levels in DXHR with a few minor differences and with a spinoff such as this it pays to give customers a new aspect of the franchise and activities not seen in its parent game (DXHR)I do think that there is potential in this game but if the developers really want it to sell then they're going to have a serious change of direction.

												This an admirable game. Yes, it has it's flaws, but it was not originally meant for PC. Ports are not easy to revamp for other systems, especially for side projects. content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												This is a straight port from the game designed for iOS. It is not a "remaster", nor does it claim to be. It is not a badly done port of that game, but anyone expecting a full-featured PC game is going to be unhappy with this. A lot of functionality from Deus Ex: Human Revolution isn't present in this game, and the graphics were obviously meant for a smaller screen. I did not play enough to comment on the story, apart from to say that the beginning is formulaic, and non-compelling. What voice acting I heard was noticably more robotic and self-conscious than the acting in Human Revolution. Oddly enough this is what sealed it for me. I expected the game mechanics and graphics to be less impressive than those of Human Revolution, but I expected the story and voice acting to make up for it. I didn't give it much of a chance, only playing for about 30 minutes, but the game didn't really put it's best foot forward, even with my lowered expectations.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												You can visit a strip club, go on the stage with the girls and steal the money people threw there. 10/10 would play againPeople leave their money on the ground or even throw it into garbage cans. Curse you, inflation!Women's restrooms have urinals inside. I wonder what kind of augmentations those girls have.Sometimes this game was very weird. Then again, it was much better then I had expected.It feels like an addon for Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Of course it doesn't reach its quality but you have the same skills, the same weapons, the same ways of approaching your goals.Basically, it's the same gameplay.There are few things I don't like about the game. First, you can't jump. Benches are your worst enemies. Second, it's way too easy. More difficulty levels would have been nice. Last but not least, it's very short. Finishing the game took me no more than 3 hours. I don't want to spoil anything except one sentence: "To be continued."I don't understand where all those bad reviews come from. "Bad graphics"? Seriously, what do you expect? It's a PC port of an iOS-game. "Bad gameplay"? It's more or less exactly the gameplay of Human Revolution. "Bad story"? It's good enough to keep me playing the game for 3 hours.If you like Deus Ex: Human Revolution and you can't get enough, take a look at The Fall. You can't expect the same quality, but if you can get it for little money it will be worth playing. I am definitely going to play it again because I want to try a different playing style and because I want to get all the achievements and side quests I missed during my first playthrough.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Ignore the metascore.  This game is no 46.  It is no 80, either, though.The biggest issue with The Fall is that it is a bad port, not necessarily a bad GAME.  You have no options to customise controls, menu clicking is annoyingly unresponsive, and leaving cover will sometimes go back to first person looking up at the sky for no reason as a default as a few gameplay flaws which were not issues on mobile.  Issues one and two did not exist because of the nature of touchscreens, and issue three never happened to me on mobile, either.  This game was not designed with PC in mind, and being hastily ported to it during Square-Enix's ♥♥♥♥♥torm politics and restructuring which began in 2012 and persists to this day was just a cash grab when it should have been delayed until it played like Deus Ex:  Human Revolution when on PC.With that being said, ten years ago this game would have been called by many players as fantastic because games were more mediocre in general (please do not bother to name rare, specific games from that era which you like as a retort since it probably not represent the shovelware climate).  In 2014, however, better quality overall is increasingly demanded by players when back then gamers were not as vocal as a whole--thank both the Internet and gaming becoming far more mainstream since the early 2000s in the west--and this is just NOT a great game by today's standards.It is, however, a definitive DE:HR sidestory experience, and it is very good in that right.  It looks, sounds, and feels like a gaiden of DE:HR and the story is great.  If you really enjoyed DE:HR or the DE series since the first like I did what with this being my favourite game series, you WILL enjoy this for about 10 or so hours.  Then, it ends, because SE decided to make it episodic content where it can charge you piecemeal for subsequent chapters.  The caveat to its piecemeal design is because the game's reception was so poor, I am largely certain that no new chapters will ever be released.  If they are, it will be more hurried content with much cut for time and budget constraints, à la the Xenosaga trilogy.The problem is not the game as much as it is how SE handled it, although the game does have its problems.  This review is simply to state that it is NOT deserving of the low 46 metascore just as sooooo many 90+ games are not even close to as deserving those high numbers...this is something that you can blame on the pay-for-scores game "journalism" paradigm of today.  Buy it on sale for $5 or less; this game sat on my Steam wishlist from its PC release date until it was $5, and I cannot recommend paying more for it even though I DO recommend playing it if you enjoy DE games.Oh, and for god's sake, if the PS2-era character models for this mobile game is the defining flaw in what makes this a "bad" game to you, you have no business critiquing any game whatsoever, let alone attempting to appreciate the DE series' level of depth and subtext beneath what are not-awful visuals.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												This was a nice game that certainly shows promise, the acting is a little bit..erm..."B"...grade, but if you look past it, the storyline is definately there. This game is too short and leaves a massive cliff hanger at the "end" telling you there will be more to come (when, what, why???). follows the Human revolution skill tree style for your augmentations, but seems limited in comparison. this may only be because of the length of the game (its a $10 or less game). If your looking for a taste of the Deus Ex franchise this game is certainly a nice but subtle taste of the world. You will find the morals and ethics of Augmentation described very well, with more insight into the "human" aspect of augmentation.I would like to rave on about how this would give insight into what the future could be like, but there is just not enough meat on the bone of this game (not like Human Revolution) but with some more "episodes" this should turn out well. The combat is okay, but slams it home that regardless of your Characters "skills" and background, going in guns blazing is almost never a good idea, you can manage fairly well if you have cover and the right gun, but stealth and non-lethal measure seem to be the key to getting things done. You aim is terrible until you get the Augmentation for both aim and recoil, but upping your cloke and silent running seems to be more effective, and as long as you have the energy, a takedown is more effective anyway. I will not harp on too much more, as the rest can be decided by yourself. I do recommend this game, but take it with an open mind and do not expect AAA game dev, but this is a nice little look into the world of Deus Ex as it currently stands.6/10

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Remember how cool the other Deus Ex games were? Dont expect that for this one. They did improove a few things Human Revolution had. First of all you can buy Any weapon or item you want and at any time. They added a hop over obsticle action when you hid behind things (however it doesnt always work and they removed the ability to jump.) However a lot of things are screwed up compared to the last game. The game models look so mechanical. Many of the characters you meet have a dead glassy stare and their bodys sometimes have badly textured looks compared to the first game. The hacking challenge is messed up. I hacked a level 5 panel without setting off anything. I hacked a level three and set it off every time. The AI is terrible and the fact bodies evaporate 5 seconds after they are knocked out or dead robs you of a little challenge in the game. The enviroments are either really nice or really bad and they use most of the old music from the last game so it feels less original. they have also got a Game chapter that Walking dead and Wolf among us has going. Ultimately this is a fun game to play for the story, not as a deus ex game. Buy it on sale but if your paying full price your going to regret it.

												good god what a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port. the keyboard and gamepad configuration was in no way the standard so upon starting the game, there was about 20 seconds worth of trying to figure out which key and button on the gamepad to go through the menu alone. Then when having difficulty with the controls layout during gameplay, it was very sad and there was ALWAYS[and i mean AAAAAAAAALLLLLLLLLLLLWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWAAAAAAAAAYYYYYYYYYYYSSSSSSSSS] the annoying tutorials as how to do literally everything. When having to sneak around the first turret in the game, they literally had a short in-game cutscene where the camera moved where you should go to sneak around the turret rather than let you use your own damn brain to come to that conclusion, another one is that when it comes to new weapons like grenades or the possible use of a new augment, you are not allowed to move unless you go through the tutorial AND it pretty much forces you to purchase whatever it is that it wants you to buy ugh, graphics suck [granted, it was poorly ported from the mobile platform so no real surprise], dialogue is poor, even the AI is extremely crappy! You have to almost unload on an enemy with your rifle at a range of less than 5 meters just to kill them, and their patrol paths are extremely basic and so predictable that you might even feel that you're just too good for this game that would be difficult only to a newborn.Oh and one thing to make note about the graphics.... while I did say that they are crappy and thats to be given since its ported from the mobile platform, the recommended specs are a complete joke. a quad core with a gtx 500 series? seriously? My laptop with an i7-4810mq and SLI 880m's with everything maxed out had the fps at 700+, now I HIGHLY doubt to run this game at a minimum of 60fps, would you even need a gtx 500 series graphics card! A hyperthreaded single core pentium 4 with a geforce 8800 series probably could do the job! [haha]So, poor AI, crappy control layout for both keyboard/mouse and gamepad, poor dialogue, overqualified hardware specs, and very annoying tutorials make this a terrible terrible game that is not worth the purchase even if they gave you money.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												I hate to have to say it, but I agree with most of the reviews and the meta score on this one. Being a huge fan of the Deus Ex game series, especially Human Revolution, I was underwhelmed when I started and completed this game. Upon purchase I saw that the game had terrible reviews and scores however since it was on sale, I decided to buy it and play it without prejudice. With that said I was extremely disappointed and I will explain why. At this stage of the game, patches have clearly fixed many of the problems that people have talked about. I had no issue with bugs in the short duration the game lasted. That if course is always a good thing.Obviously coming from playing Human Revolution, I had high expectations for this game on many levels. Upon entering the start up screen, I immediately went into check graphics settings and control settings. The options were poor to say the least. I was able to change anistrophic filtering and that was about it. There really was no other say when it came to the graphics of the game. On that note, the graphics were not that big of an issue for me. I was pleased with them. Although not as good as Human Revolution, it was perfectly fine for its purposes. Once starting the game I was interested by the story. I like were the story picked up from and how a good amount of the information could be found from in game play. Just like Human Revolution your Augs can greatly help you evaluate conversations. Unfortunately there were not many coversations to be had. Even for the short duration, there are only three or four side missions that you come across without trying extremely hard. The missions are easy and just simply involve a lot of travel between the few small levels of the small map. That is my next issue. Travel in this game is boring! There are only five or six trully distinct locations that you must travel to in order to complete the game. An hour into the game, I felt like I was just going back and forth constantly and I was already bored enough to put the game down. The duration of the game however is my ultimate issue. Not having read any of the comments for this game, i really was expecting another full on Deus Ex game. By the game description and the story that starts to unfold, you would expect so much more, rather than a To Be Continued. I love Deus Ex to the point where I search every single room, air duct and storage unit. Even thouroughly searching through the game, It only took me four hours to complete. i was just messing around looking around and only took that long! Overall the Deus Ex series is amazing but this game, at this point at least, is honestly not worth it. I was extremely disappointed that I bothered with it. The only real reason to have it is to say you at least own every game in the series. Thats all it's really good for. If you do choose to buy this game, do not get your hopes up and set any expectations you have extremely low. I really don't enjoy having to right a poor review for a game especially such as this series, but such a horrible game warrants such a review. Best of luck to anyone who does decide to play. At least you can play the game again with all your current augs and purchases but on an increased difficulty.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												I recommend it with some conditions. It's not a very good game, but I still found enough fun to be worth my time. If you consider this a higher quality fan mod (which is about the level of quality to expect here, not that it is an actual fan mod), there is some fun to be had here. Obviously, expecting this to be comparable to Human Revolutions or even the original Deus Ex will only result in dissapointment. VOICE ACTINGThe voice acting is pretty bad, but a lot better than I've seen from some fan mods that have tried to do voice acting.  The dialogue options are extremely limited, with very few opportunities for it to make a difference.STORYIt's ok and it keeps the pace going. GAMEPLAYA lot of areas are streamlined, probably primarily to do it being originally a mobile game. No jumping, which I disliked, but I can see why one might cut that here. It gives the designers a lot more control over where a player can go in the game without having to design additional ways to block player movement to account for jumping. This also focuses the type of gameplay they are offering, allowing multiple ways through environments. STEALTHI liked that full stealth options were available, as well as guns ablazing. HACKINGMuch easier than in Human Revolutions, but plenty of things to hack and a few good opportunities to turn robots and turrets against your enemies. GOODSI noticed a ton of weapons available for purchase... though I never bought any. The store might be too easy to access, but it gave a lot more options than typically can be found. Everything is probably too plentiful in the game. LEVELINGLeveling up was really quick, which was good since the game was short.ONE SAVE + BUGSI hate single save options. Just make sure when you save, nothing screwy is happening, though I found only a couple bugs during my playthrough.FINAL THOUGHTSIf anything, the game is too easy, but I still found it fun and I'm interested in seeing where things might go next, if they still planned on making another one. It's a nice diversion, as long as you don't expect much from it. Buy it on sale, if interested, and you should be good.

												This is a seriously dumbed-down version of the "Deus ex experience" in every aspect: gameplay, maps, characters, shop system, controls, 4-dummy-tutorials... - and even story and dialogue are mostly not very inspired, but not entirely uninteresting either...However, it gets better after the tutorial-heavy intro and, for me, it turned out to be much better than expected after all the negative reviews. Design and music are ok at least and produce a good Deus ex feeling despite all the flaws of the game. Recommended if you want more Deus ex atmosphere and dont mind everything being dumbed-down quite a bit. In other words: keep your expectations in check and dont hope for it being DX: HR2. Also, get it on sale, not for the full price...EDIT: I cannot recommend this game anymore - even on sale - after playing through it, since it is really very very very short... the normal price is a joke.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												You can visit a strip club, go on the stage with the girls and steal the money people threw there. 10/10 would play againPeople leave their money on the ground or even throw it into garbage cans. Curse you, inflation!Women's restrooms have urinals inside. I wonder what kind of augmentations those girls have.Sometimes this game was very weird. Then again, it was much better then I had expected.It feels like an addon for Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Of course it doesn't reach its quality but you have the same skills, the same weapons, the same ways of approaching your goals.Basically, it's the same gameplay.There are few things I don't like about the game. First, you can't jump. Benches are your worst enemies. Second, it's way too easy. More difficulty levels would have been nice. Last but not least, it's very short. Finishing the game took me no more than 3 hours. I don't want to spoil anything except one sentence: "To be continued."I don't understand where all those bad reviews come from. "Bad graphics"? Seriously, what do you expect? It's a PC port of an iOS-game. "Bad gameplay"? It's more or less exactly the gameplay of Human Revolution. "Bad story"? It's good enough to keep me playing the game for 3 hours.If you like Deus Ex: Human Revolution and you can't get enough, take a look at The Fall. You can't expect the same quality, but if you can get it for little money it will be worth playing. I am definitely going to play it again because I want to try a different playing style and because I want to get all the achievements and side quests I missed during my first playthrough.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Gentlemen, the secret passage is in the ladies' lavatory.So I played the game through, and just when it was about to get interesting, there was a TO BE CONTINUED.  Bear in mind that it took 5.8 hours to get interesting (I'm pretty sure at least one of those hours was preparing a soup from scratch and then eating it).  I expect the TO BE CONTINUED will be another equal waste of cash.So the gameplay is largely the same as Deus Ex, except you start with the Icarus Wings falling system.  Not that there are any heights to fall from, so that's useless.  There's no jump button, so anything you're looking for -- such air vents (!) -- is at floor level.  The "numerous" side-quests the overview boasts is about 5.  The levels are claustrophobic and tiny, which I understand to be a hold-over from being a mobile game.  You get just enough cash through the game to buy maybe one of the "bundles" (!), or one of the advanced weapons, just before the game is over.  There don't appear to be many meaningful decisions to make with dialogs, in-game choices, in the way that other games in the series have.  The story *could* be interesting, but it isn't yet.In short, this game is a Deus Ex game, but with far less Deus Ex than a Deus Ex game should have.  It's a thorough "meh."  As such, even though it provided a vaguely entertaining Sunday afternoon, I can't really recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Oh, boy, this game.Upon completion of this game after roughly 7 hours and watching a very scathing review by TotalBiscuit, I have some thoughts. This game, unlike many iOS franchise ports, is very true to Deus Ex (and it better be, if it's canon). Now, I'm not a fanboy of the series (yet), after putting a good deal of time into both Human Revolution and the original Deus Ex, I'd say this upholds the atmosphere and mechanics very well.The game has a NewGame+ mode, a necessity for its expensive weapon upgrades and miniscule size. Again, judging it on the basis of an iOS game, it is a GREAT game. However, as TotalBiscuit pointed out, it's not an iOS game anymore - it's on PC, and we need to rate it like that.I know I'll get a lot of ire for saying this, but the gameplay is very alike to Half-Life; open spaces and cramped corridors and a huge sandbox for tackling such spaces. The augmentations in the game provide the most variability in encounters. And that's where it gets admittedly strange. The augmentations (20 in total) are super easy to get. In HR, it takes a metric ton of experience to unlock a point, and finding one in the levels were few and far between, and were ludicrously expensive to get in stores. But The Fall doesn't have lengthy campaign levels to trek through and rank XP, and most oddly, there are no stores in Fall - your pause menu is your store. This really does seem like laziness on the developer end and feels cheaty - it's basically a currency-based devmode, and I assume this is where the iOS version made use of microtransactions, which are thankfully absent from the PC. A basic shotgun can put you back a couple thousand credits (and you usually pick up credits in the world in valus around 30), but an augment that lets you punch through walls is a mere 20 headshots away, and the of the few levels present, I'd say about 80% of them have a praxis kit in them somewhere.Where we depart from Half-Life are the RPG mechanics. Conversations here are lackluster, though voice acting on actual characters is well done (on the random NPCs it is just terrible) very little information other than necessary to the plot is given, and don't really require investment to understand. The conversation augment makes this basically null and void, allowing you to just press a button to automatically give you everything you need to complete a quest. HR's version of the same augment still required you to pay attention to on-screen cues and dialogue from the character you're speaking with, the augment just nudges you in the right direction when the clues get too subtle.Onto the thing that made TotalBiscuit destroy this game; the controls are horrible. Seriously, very little effort seemed to be put into making this a good PC port. Controls cannot be re-assigned, their given slots are awkward and not reflexive in any way. TotalBiscuit complained about his mouse acting up and keys being ignored at random, and he criticized the "recoil" system of zooming out every time you fire. I found the key: xbox controller! The controls for the 360 link work perfectly. I had no problems with button presses or controls, though there was still no button reassigning and it insisted on using X for "enter" instead of A.Combat is also affected by its iOS roots. I think most gamers are used to cover based combat like Mass Effect, where you click into cover, peek out, and fire, all separate motions. In The Fall, firstly, you hold the cover button (like you do in HR as well), which can get a little wonky where the game can't tell if you want to shimmy backwards or turn around. Though annoying, it's easily fixed by simply dropping out of cover and going again - it's annoying, but not as punishing compared to doing the same thing in Mass Effect. Once in cover, you aim and fire a bullet. That isn't two steps, it's one. You sortof have to aim from cover (which changes when you physically move out to shoot), then press the fire button. You end up with a very snappy pointshootcover dynamic, but it's disorienting if you're not expecting it. Basically, there was no reason for me to bother with anything else than the pistol, especially once I had a laser sight, because I would be only squeezing off a round at a time anyways, and worse came to worse, I could cover the classic way and just crouch behind chest-high walls, peeking around a corner manually.It's by no means a difficult game. This is good because it has a horrible property of only having one save slot, which autosaves every time you enter a new area. One the bright side, your quicksave key makes an actual save, so you don't have to sit through a saving wheel. However, you have to be a lot more careful with what you do, because you only have one save to fall back on.Getting nitpicky, there's no real difference between lethal and nonlethal combat. Whether you KO them or kill them, the body evaporates after a second or so on the ground, leaving a gun and a wallet behind. In HR, there was an actual choice between the two, because a KO'd enemy can be woken up over time or by a conscious goon. In Fall, you only have to choose between a wider variety of weapons to kill with, or a quieter takedown.PROS-+It's a neat story, true to the Deus Ex universe+an interesting graphic style (I'm running on Intel graphics, guys, I'm not big on the graphics, but it looks cool and runs smoothly)+entertaining gameplay+NewGame+ solves many of its currency shenangans, allows you to enjoy the sandbox moreCONS--you NEED a 360 controller to play it, and no key reassigning to fix this-awkward currency choices an implementation-Microscopic campaign, under 10 side quests-Not a challenge by any stretch of the imaginationIf you want a snappy shooter you can blow through in a day and be a cyborg in, or if you are a fan of thre Deus Ex franchise, this is a good game worthy of the time. That being said, the pricetag is way too high for a tiny game with not really much replay value. It could be better, but it didn't measure up to the horror stories. If you're going to get it, get it on sale and keep an open mind, and I'd bet you'll have fun with it.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I'm not sure why this game has such a bad reputation. For an iOS port the graphics aren't abysmal,  which was one knock I kept seeing throughout reviews. People have complained of "unresponsive controls;" this is only the case in menus where you're not in a time crunch and simply have to click a second time for it to work...not a big deal.  The gameplay was fun, coming from somebody that has played the entire Deus Ex franchise from beginning to end. For $9.99 I've been very satisfied with the game so far (I got it for $4.99 on sale so even better). The only real thing I didn't like was the voice acting felt very subpar but I worry about gameplay not voice acting.tl;dr: get this game on sale if you're skeptical and you'll get your money's worth.  The "issues" aren't really that big of a deal and its a good Deus Ex game at its core.Overall I'd give it a 7/10.

												While going through the tutorial I really felt like this was a god aweful game... but only until I finished the tutorial and got into the actual game.I have played Deus Ex: Human Revolution so I knew what to expect and had high expectations, even though I knew this was a port of a mobile game. While it isn't as realized or complex as Human Revolution, I had fun the 5-6 hours it took me to get through it.While there are no micro transactions in the PC version of the game, you can still feel how the item shop was designed to give people the opportunity to spend real money on the game whenever they found themselves in a sticky situation - you can buy anything, ANYTHING that is available in the game on the fly, but it costs in-game currency in the PC port so you obviously can't be loaded with gear from the get-go.I give Deus Ex: The Fall 6/10 and I find the 2 Euro I spent on it was worth it (got it at reduced price - I probably won't recommend it at its full price).

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												This is a straight port from the game designed for iOS. It is not a "remaster", nor does it claim to be. It is not a badly done port of that game, but anyone expecting a full-featured PC game is going to be unhappy with this. A lot of functionality from Deus Ex: Human Revolution isn't present in this game, and the graphics were obviously meant for a smaller screen. I did not play enough to comment on the story, apart from to say that the beginning is formulaic, and non-compelling. What voice acting I heard was noticably more robotic and self-conscious than the acting in Human Revolution. Oddly enough this is what sealed it for me. I expected the game mechanics and graphics to be less impressive than those of Human Revolution, but I expected the story and voice acting to make up for it. I didn't give it much of a chance, only playing for about 30 minutes, but the game didn't really put it's best foot forward, even with my lowered expectations.

												This an admirable game. Yes, it has it's flaws, but it was not originally meant for PC. Ports are not easy to revamp for other systems, especially for side projects. This game has a great story, has all the features from the original game, and is a great experience. You cannot jump, or remap buttons, but that's not a big deal. The only problem I had was scrolling through the weapons list with my mouse wheel, but that's really it. The graphics are not up to date. This is a great buy at any price you buy it at. The only thing that bugs me is that it is half a story, and the dlc is no where in sight.3/5. I reccomend for all Deus Ex fans.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I'm glad I didn't pay full price for this game. It certainly isn't even worth the money I paid for it! Now, where to begin....the graphics are horrid, and the dialogue is only slightly better. The fact that I can't jump is really frustrating as it took me a few minutes to figure out how to get over a low wall. Also, the game forces you to put a silencer on a combat rifle, which is horrid in itself. I'm much more of a pistol person myself, so it was extremely frustrating to be forced to use the combat rifle to stay at least somewhat hidden. However, the worst part of it all is that the silencer doesn't even work - the enemies responded the same!The controls themselves are extremely confusing. Instead of using the numbers to change weapons like pretty much every other game in the world does, you're stuck holding down buttons on the keyboard and then scrolling through the options. If you want to change a weapon quickly in battle, tough luck.Also, for some reason, I can't get headshots, even though I have no trouble getting them in DX:HR. It's frustrating to use up so much ammo on such a simple guard. Granted, there is an in-game store to replenish you ammo, but I feel that really doesn't fit - after all, there's no challenge if you can pull up the store in the middle of a fight and buy a grenade.Anyway, save your money. Buy Deus Ex: Human Revolution instead.

												Deus ex the fall destroys anything than made deus ex human revolution great, invisible walls, boring storyline, dull voice acting, a campaign than lasts 2-3 hours at most and they have the audacity of leaving a cliffhanger ending saying this is just part 1 they even charge a total of 10$ for a ios port game, i highly doubt they will ever make the sequel so don't bother buying the game at full price, nor during discounts, if you really want to play this wait for a  bundle, it has been already been in one.The graphics and animations are notably worse than the previous human revolution even though this game came out after.There's a obviously intended micro transaction system where you can buy stuff like 10 praxis kits for 10k bundle, in the pc version you don't have to pay a dime but they didn't fix the prices either.The story is about Ben Saxon an ex soldier who's squad been wiped and got recruited into the tyrants, he's probably the most gullible hero ever in a sci fi game, trying to expose the tyrants.Even tho this game is a prequel there's no relation to the human revolution at all except the tyrants, and only two of them are voiced, but one of the only barely says 2 lines in the entire game.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												They pushed an update August 1, 2014 that corrected many issues. I'll change my rating to a 'thumbs up' but do notice that it took them that long to make the patch. My original review is below. 


Announcement: Deus Ex The Fall Patch 1.0.1 Update 
Deus Ex: The Fall, Aug 1, 2014

			Hey folks, Firstly, thanks for all your constructive feedback. I’d also like to thank you all for your patience. I know it’s been a while since release, but we’ve been working hard in implementing...		


==================While I like this game for it's low budget cyberpunk feel, I can't honestly recommend it until they correct some issues.- The audio is broken on surround sound systems. Set your audio device to stereo to fix that problem.- Sometimes there is a slow-down that is apparently due to memory management.- The game environment sometimes disappears and you just see the background image.- I've teleported places after jumping over objects or climbing ladders.Last time I was teleported into a wall, I got the bright idea to save the game and reload... nope, still stuck in a wall.You have one save slot so my game is ruined unless maybe I find a trainer that will let me no-clip out.It's not a terrible game (I'm easy to please) because I like the feel of it and it has some story info that supports Human Revolution, but it is a poor port and due to the issues this game has I don't recommend buying it unless you pay less than $1.UPDATE 1:I started a new game, it played fine, and I completed it. The only change I made was that I set my video card (GTX 780) to adaptive power management (NVIDIA CP, 3D settings). Not sure if that mattered, but that was the only change; no more teleporting. The game is still a buggy mess but I enjoyed the story. I actually liked the audio but it's too bad that it doesn't work in surround mode.I won't change my recommendation because the game needs work.UPDATE 2:Getting all achievements in this game is fairly easy so I played through a total of 2.5 times to get the achievements. On my second playthrough I got stuck in a wall again; actually I was just stuck against a wall, I guess. Same way, climbed a ladder or maybe I tried to move a heavy box.I found that by using the Stealth Dash that you could then move around. Stealth Dash yourself to the nearest ladder and climb it, this will let you freely move again but some things may still be broken (I couldn't open a grate or move some boxes). Use a trainer if you don't have the resources to buy Stealth Dash but be careful that the trainer doesn't load you up with money/praxis kits and ruin any challenge.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												This was a nice game that certainly shows promise, the acting is a little bit..erm..."B"...grade, but if you look past it, the storyline is definately there. This game is too short and leaves a massive cliff hanger at the "end" telling you there will be more to come (when, what, why???). follows the Human revolution skill tree style for your augmentations, but seems limited in comparison. this may only be because of the length of the game (its a $10 or less game). If your looking for a taste of the Deus Ex franchise this game is certainly a nice but subtle taste of the world. You will find the morals and ethics of Augmentation described very well, with more insight into the "human" aspect of augmentation.I would like to rave on about how this would give insight into what the future could be like, but there is just not enough meat on the bone of this game (not like Human Revolution) but with some more "episodes" this should turn out well. The combat is okay, but slams it home that regardless of your Characters "skills" and background, going in guns blazing is almost never a good idea, you can manage fairly well if you have cover and the right gun, but stealth and non-lethal measure seem to be the key to getting things done. You aim is terrible until you get the Augmentation for both aim and recoil, but upping your cloke and silent running seems to be more effective, and as long as you have the energy, a takedown is more effective anyway. I will not harp on too much more, as the rest can be decided by yourself. I do recommend this game, but take it with an open mind and do not expect AAA game dev, but this is a nice little look into the world of Deus Ex as it currently stands.6/10

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												good god what a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port. the keyboard and gamepad configuration was in no way the standard so upon starting the game, there was about 20 seconds worth of trying to figure out which key and button on the gamepad to go through the menu alone. Then when having difficulty with the controls layout during gameplay, it was very sad and there was ALWAYS[and i mean AAAAAAAAALLLLLLLLLLLLWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWAAAAAAAAAYYYYYYYYYYYSSSSSSSSS] the annoying tutorials as how to do literally everything. When having to sneak around the first turret in the game, they literally had a short in-game cutscene where the camera moved where you should go to sneak around the turret rather than let you use your own damn brain to come to that conclusion, another one is that when it comes to new weapons like grenades or the possible use of a new augment, you are not allowed to move unless you go through the tutorial AND it pretty much forces you to purchase whatever it is that it wants you to buy ugh, graphics suck [granted, it was poorly ported from the mobile platform so no real surprise], dialogue is poor, even the AI is extremely crappy! You have to almost unload on an enemy with your rifle at a range of less than 5 meters just to kill them, and their patrol paths are extremely basic and so predictable that you might even feel that you're just too good for this game that would be difficult only to a newborn.Oh and one thing to make note about the graphics.... while I did say that they are crappy and thats to be given since its ported from the mobile platform, the recommended specs are a complete joke. a quad core with a gtx 500 series? seriously? My laptop with an i7-4810mq and SLI 880m's with everything maxed out had the fps at 700+, now I HIGHLY doubt to run this game at a minimum of 60fps, would you even need a gtx 500 series graphics card! A hyperthreaded single core pentium 4 with a geforce 8800 series probably could do the job! [haha]So, poor AI, crappy control layout for both keyboard/mouse and gamepad, poor dialogue, overqualified hardware specs, and very annoying tutorials make this a terrible terrible game that is not worth the purchase even if they gave you money.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Gentlemen, the secret passage is in the ladies' lavatory.So I played the game through, and just when it was about to get interesting, there was a TO BE CONTINUED.  Bear in mind that it took 5.8 hours to get interesting (I'm pretty sure at least one of those hours was preparing a soup from scratch and then eating it).  I expect the TO BE CONTINUED will be another equal waste of cash.So the gameplay is largely the same as Deus Ex, except you start with the Icarus Wings falling system.  Not that there are any heights to fall from, so that's useless.  There's no jump button, so anything you're looking for -- such air vents (!) -- is at floor level.  The "numerous" side-quests the overview boasts is about 5.  The levels are claustrophobic and tiny, which I understand to be a hold-over from being a mobile game.  You get just enough cash through the game to buy maybe one of the "bundles" (!), or one of the advanced weapons, just before the game is over.  There don't appear to be many meaningful decisions to make with dialogs, in-game choices, in the way that other games in the series have.  The story *could* be interesting, but it isn't yet.In short, this game is a Deus Ex game, but with far less Deus Ex than a Deus Ex game should have.  It's a thorough "meh."  As such, even though it provided a vaguely entertaining Sunday afternoon, I can't really recommend it.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Ignore the metascore.  This game is no 46.  It is no 80, either, though.The biggest issue with The Fall is that it is a bad port, not necessarily a bad GAME.  You have no options to customise controls, menu clicking is annoyingly unresponsive, and leaving cover will sometimes go back to first person looking up at the sky for no reason as a default as a few gameplay flaws which were not issues on mobile.  Issues one and two did not exist because of the nature of touchscreens, and issue three never happened to me on mobile, either.  This game was not designed with PC in mind, and being hastily ported to it during Square-Enix's ♥♥♥♥♥torm politics and restructuring which began in 2012 and persists to this day was just a cash grab when it should have been delayed until it played like Deus Ex:  Human Revolution when on PC.With that being said, ten years ago this game would have been called by many players as fantastic because games were more mediocre in general (please do not bother to name rare, specific games from that era which you like as a retort since it probably not represent the shovelware climate).  In 2014, however, better quality overall is increasingly demanded by players when back then gamers were not as vocal as a whole--thank both the Internet and gaming becoming far more mainstream since the early 2000s in the west--and this is just NOT a great game by today's standards.It is, however, a definitive DE:HR sidestory experience, and it is very good in that right.  It looks, sounds, and feels like a gaiden of DE:HR and the story is great.  If you really enjoyed DE:HR or the DE series since the first like I did what with this being my favourite game series, you WILL enjoy this for about 10 or so hours.  Then, it ends, because SE decided to make it episodic content where it can charge you piecemeal for subsequent chapters.  The caveat to its piecemeal design is because the game's reception was so poor, I am largely certain that no new chapters will ever be released.  If they are, it will be more hurried content with much cut for time and budget constraints, à la the Xenosaga trilogy.The problem is not the game as much as it is how SE handled it, although the game does have its problems.  This review is simply to state that it is NOT deserving of the low 46 metascore just as sooooo many 90+ games are not even close to as deserving those high numbers...this is something that you can blame on the pay-for-scores game "journalism" paradigm of today.  Buy it on sale for $5 or less; this game sat on my Steam wishlist from its PC release date until it was $5, and I cannot recommend paying more for it even though I DO recommend playing it if you enjoy DE games.Oh, and for god's sake, if the PS2-era character models for this mobile game is the defining flaw in what makes this a "bad" game to you, you have no business critiquing any game whatsoever, let alone attempting to appreciate the DE series' level of depth and subtext beneath what are not-awful visuals.

Posted: August 3, 2014
												Nearly everything about this game is terrible - the voice acting, the dialogues, the facial animations from end of 90s, the combat, the tedious voice recordings in the first part of the game (which kinda felt like they were just reciting the book, which I read long ago so I'm not sure about that). the annoying lack of jumping. Also, disappearing walls and objects during takedown animation. And yes, I'm pretty sure I've only seen a one single takedown animation throughout the whole game.The only thing they didn't break is stealth, although level design is over 9000 percent worse than in DX:HR.Also, I'm usually not the person to complain about graphics (I still play some games from late 80s from time to time), but I'm pretty sure I've seen better graphics in games on my iPhone.One the bright side, it only took me 5 hours to complete the game, finishing some side quests and exploring a little bit.In conclusion, if you are desperate for some more Deus Ex, better replay the original and/or HR once more, or read the book, which is, although not exactly a masterpiece, still way better than this game.
