content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												Deus Ex: The Fall is the prequel to Deus Ex: Human Revolution. I found the original Deus Ex and Invisible War to be out dated in their mechanics, while Human Revolution made everything smoother and more enjoyable. Deus Ex: The Fall tries to be Human Revolution, but fails miserably:- The AI is just bad. I am talking Stormtrooper level of bad. Their aiming is very poor and standing behind a hip-height cover or being on the opposite side of the room will win you a fire fight. Also, their spotting is completely off. Sneaking isn't fun in this game because you have next to no challenge. The enemies are lined up to be taken out undetected and even otherwise, the enemies seem to just have forgotten that they should be on alert.- The shooting.. Holy mother of god. I know this is a mobile port but man.. they screwed up big times here. The weapons are lame and after firing your gun the screen shakes like it just started a rave party. After ever shot of the pistole and the shotgun it massivly zooms in and out.. not sure if I should call this recoil or ravecoil since there is no real weapon spread when spraying. Additionally, the guns are unresponsive and ignore certain actions from time to time.- There is no inventory managment. You can just buy any item you need right on the battlefield and they are teleported into your inventory. Probably a leftover from micro-transactions of the mobile version.- The options are ridiculous. No real PC options. Even indie game with Unity have better optimisation. The mouse control is awful and seems to have problems all over the place.- The graphics aren't terrible. They remind of Human Revolution and I like the overall aesthetic better than in Deus Ex 1 or Invisible War. Unfortunatly, the textures and models are muddy, lifeless and low resolution. To sum it up.. old. No improvment to the mobile version. The animations are clunky and take too long for rapid responsives and are sluggish as hell.- The gameplay is like an old demo of Human Revolution. Cover system, sneaking, hacking.. all good when looking at it but it just feels clunky. The cover system is also plagued with issues like clipping into textures, seeing the skybox, ignoring a wall, refusing to go in or out of cover or even just sticking to the air and act like its a wall. At least it has the basic elements of Human Revolution: Takedown, sneaking, hacking key pads...- The missions. The game in general is very short but you have at least a few side missions and different approaches (leathal, non-leathal, range..). The levels are in response to that also fairly small. I played it through in two hours and idled the rest for cards.To sum it up: Blind AI, bad resource managment, few settings, outdated graphics, poor gameplay and short gamelength.I found it rather to be enjoyable as a joke since I got it for free but paying 10€ for it is more than a rip-off.

												I haven't played video games in a very long time and lost interest in them completely until I decided to download the Steam platform and become a part of the PC gaming crowd (which is a hell of a lot more fun, interesting, and less alienating than the console platform, IMO).For someone who isn't well acquainted with the Deus Ex franchise, I saw this game as a bit of a fun primer that will help me get through the meat of the main franchise (Deus Ex, Invisible War, Human Revolution, and eventually Mankind Divided). And even if I was a veteran of the franchise, I would enjoy Deus Ex: The Fall for what it is: another story in the Deus Ex Universe.With that said, Deus Ex: The Fall doesn't deserve the shade everyone is giving it. I played it, beat the initial campaign on a no-kill playthrough, and enjoyed it. Especially since I am a big fan of stealth games like Metal Gear Solid, and of the cyberpunk genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												When a new Deus Ex game comes out, fans of the series gobble it up like baby ducks.  You can bet gamers were salivating behind their monitors when they saw there was a new installment in the series.  Unfortunately, they will have to endure the never ending wait till Mankind Divided, because the Fall just does not carry the banner.  With the exception of some decent shading and lighting effects, graphics that might look halfway decent on a mobile device barely look better than the 2003 graphics of Invisible War.  Although The Fall has a faux version of the signature look of Human Revolution, it is simplified, and scaled down so far in detail that the level designs suffer.  It feels more like you're running through mazes than playing a modern FPS/RPG hybrid.  The salt wouldn't sting so bad if it had the same signature stealth system we knew from Deus Ex Classic.  In The Fall, enemies are so sensitive they practically have eyes in the backs of their heads.  Also, the movement is pretty clunky, so running around shooting everyone isn't always the best solution either.  There is some good writing along the way, but the overall plot is fairly simple, with much fewer side missions than there are in the mainstay Deus Ex titles.I would bet that absolute diehard fans of the series might be able to force themselves to play this for the sake of completion.  Then again, we don't get much of a sense who these characters are within the scope of the Jensen, Denton, and Denton team.  Those who are not familiar with the series but looking for a fun stealth shooter with  RPG elements would be far better just to start with Deus Ex Classic, then work their way up through the Invisible War and Human Revolution.________________________________________________________________Above was my original review in which I gave The Fall a thumbs down.  However, after playing the game more, I actually decided to revisit my assessment of the game.  While all of the things I said at first still apply.  There are a few really annoying things, like the addition of a persistant market instead of having NPC vendors located around the world.  It is designed for mobiles devices, and I think it would look better on a tablet than on a PC.  Was Eidos lazy in pushing out a game that could have been quite a bit better if they were willing to invest a little more into it?  Yes!  But in the end, if you can get past the dated graphics and bugs the game does feel like a Deus Ex game at heart.  Because of that, I would have to say it's worth playing for any fans of the series.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												I re-played Human Revolution after a few years, and when I finished, I decided to give The Fall a shot.It pains me to say that Deus Ex: The Fall is so disappointing as to be nearly unplayable.  It's Human Revolution just... less.  It looks like a third party came in and just made every aspect of the game worse: buttons often have to be clicked multiple times to work, cover works differently, the inventory/shop systems are completely different, and even hacking, which was super minimalistic to begin with, is now quite a lot worse.I put in two hours and I just can't keep going.  If you're hardcore enough to push through for the sake of the story, good on you, but I simply can't say that this game is *fun* in any way.  The graphics are similar to the original, but the voice acting is poor, and even the storyline is shoddy.  If you're looking for a good gaming experience, don't touch this with a ten-foot pole.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Nearly everything about this game is terrible - the voice acting, the dialogues, the facial animations from end of 90s, the combat, the tedious voice recordings in the first part of the game (which kinda felt like they were just reciting the book, which I read long ago so I'm not sure about that). the annoying lack of jumping. Also, disappearing walls and objects during takedown animation. 												Game mechanics take awhile to get used to.  This type of game should have a jump option but this one doesn't making me miss JC Denton's 4" vertical leap... I give it a solid "meh" and worth it if you get it cheap.Tangent:  I was able to play this using my old Core i5-2500K's integrated graphics, nothing overclocked.  Playing this way allowed me to save ~100KWH compared to using my Radeon HD 7950.  Will continue to find ways to save the planet by finding other games where good-enough-graphics will work.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												Deus Ex: The Fall is the prequel to Deus Ex: Human Revolution. I found the original Deus Ex and Invisible War to be out dated in their mechanics, while Human Revolution made everything smoother and more enjoyable. Deus Ex: The Fall tries to be Human Revolution, but fails miserably:- The AI is just bad. I am talking Stormtrooper level of bad. Their aiming is very poor and standing behind a hip-height cover or being on the opposite side of the room will win you a fire fight. Also, their spotting is completely off. Sneaking isn't fun in this game because you have next to no challenge. The enemies are lined up to be taken out undetected and even otherwise, the enemies seem to just have forgotten that they should be on alert.- The shooting.. Holy mother of god. I know this is a mobile port but man.. they screwed up big times here. The weapons are lame and after firing your gun the screen shakes like it just started a rave party. After ever shot of the pistole and the shotgun it massivly zooms in and out.. not sure if I should call this recoil or ravecoil since there is no real weapon spread when spraying. Additionally, the guns are unresponsive and ignore certain actions from time to time.- There is no inventory managment. You can just buy any item you need right on the battlefield and they are teleported into your inventory. Probably a leftover from micro-transactions of the mobile version.- The options are ridiculous. No real PC options. Even indie game with Unity have better optimisation. The mouse control is awful and seems to have problems all over the place.- The graphics aren't terrible. They remind of Human Revolution and I like the overall aesthetic better than in Deus Ex 1 or Invisible War. Unfortunatly, the textures and models are muddy, lifeless and low resolution. To sum it up.. old. No improvment to the mobile version. The animations are clunky and take too long for rapid responsives and are sluggish as hell.- The gameplay is like an old demo of Human Revolution. Cover system, sneaking, hacking.. all good when looking at it but it just feels clunky. The cover system is also plagued with issues like clipping into textures, seeing the skybox, ignoring a wall, refusing to go in or out of cover or even just sticking to the air and act like its a wall. At least it has the basic elements of Human Revolution: Takedown, sneaking, hacking key pads...- The missions. The game in general is very short but you have at least a few side missions and different approaches (leathal, non-leathal, range..). The levels are in response to that also fairly small. I played it through in two hours and idled the rest for cards.To sum it up: Blind AI, bad resource managment, few settings, outdated graphics, poor gameplay and short gamelength.I found it rather to be enjoyable as a joke since I got it for free but paying 10€ for it is more than a rip-off.

												The Fall isn't a game that I would recommend for a Deus Ex experience.Pros:For a mobile game it does have some good backgroundsSaxon who is the player character has some potential in terms of story and character building.I actually liked the plane level and the turntable was a nice feature.Cons:Gameplay tries but fails to emulate Deus Ex HRThe story didn't really catch my attention and I often skipped quite a bit of the dialogue. I do think that think that there is a story there but it’s just presented in such a bland way that you just switch offOh and the weapon animations are horribleThe first (tutorial) mission felt really quite bland which is a shame considering the venue was Moscow which could have been interesting.It's unfinished. To be frank there's a whole list of other things that have gone wrong with this game which has already been pointed out.And if I was asked to develop a game for mobile platforms and PC then I would not have chosen an FPS format.In short: Do not purchase this game and definitely not at full price although I purchased this as part of a bundle.Recommendations:I would turn this into a top down RPG instead although this may have to sacrifice some Deus Ex features but you could end up with much better gameplay and graphics which doesn't look quite so wanting and still be able to have acceptable looking custcenes.Get rid of the purchase menu; I don't know what they were thinking by including that.Also the environments need to be better developed. The Panama level just felt like a copy and paste of the Detroit levels in DXHR with a few minor differences and with a spinoff such as this it pays to give customers a new aspect of the franchise and activities not seen in its parent game (DXHR)I do think that there is potential in this game but if the developers really want it to sell then they're going to have a serious change of direction.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												This is a straight port from the game designed for iOS. It is not a "remaster", nor does it claim to be. It is not a badly done port of that game, but anyone expecting a full-featured PC game is going to be unhappy with this. A lot of functionality from Deus Ex: Human Revolution isn't present in this game, and the graphics were obviously meant for a smaller screen. I did not play enough to comment on the story, apart from to say that the beginning is formulaic, and non-compelling. What voice acting I heard was noticably more robotic and self-conscious than the acting in Human Revolution. Oddly enough this is what sealed it for me. I expected the game mechanics and graphics to be less impressive than those of Human Revolution, but I expected the story and voice acting to make up for it. I didn't give it much of a chance, only playing for about 30 minutes, but the game didn't really put it's best foot forward, even with my lowered expectations.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 19
												Alright, so this is my first review ever, but I wanted to jump in since the game is getting a lot of hate and I aim to justify the existence of this entry and to tell you how not everything is as bad as many people say. If you are unsure about this game let me tell you this: this game will only please a select few hardcore fans, so if you are one, this could be a gamble. If you are not a big a fan, save your money and time, and play the big titles instead. Prepare for a wall of text.Before anything else, I need you to know that the book "Deus Ex: Icarus Effect" written by James Swallow (main writer for the modern DX games) is canon and takes places before the events of this game and not only introduces all of the characters mentioned in The Fall, but also talks about many events that impact the game and Human Revolution as well. For you to maximize the enjoyment of the game, read the book (if you have the patience) or the summary  here [deusex.wikia.com]. Doing so will give you a deeper sense of the narrative and perhaps a different perspective when you play this game, seeing as the novel basically sets up this game. The game takes place after the events of the book, and follows the story of Ben Saxon and the Tyrants, the group of mercenaries that attack Sarif Industries on DX Human Revolution.Let me start with the bad things about the game: Deus Ex: The Fall is simply a PC port for a mobile game that came out in 2013, so do not get you hopes up about nice features, big areas and details like in DXHR or DXMD. That being said, the port is simply a copy paste from the mobile versions with graphic upscaling and Anti Aliasing and added keyboard support, everything else is the same and it feels really limited. The game is very short, bodies disappear, enemy AI is bound to a specific area and they do not go past said area, the controls feel clunky and many other limitations exist (and it makes sense for a mobile game), there is no inventory management and there are no physical shops in the game. You can simply pause the game, go into the different parts of the menus and purchase anything at any moment using in-game currency, and you can carry everything that is available to use by the player without consequence. It is practical, but not challenging to use this system. You also only have one save slot and this is terrible for a PC port, this should be unaccpetable, but here we are. Finally, the story starts off slowly and it's not very interesting at the beginning. Some characters are oversimplified and feel bland, but the story is still somewhat interesting for those who aren't hardcore fans. The game is supposedly episodic, but only part 1 has been released so far and you will be left in a cliffhanger. No talk about part 2 is making people angry and uneasy about this game's future, and rightfully so.Now, the good things! The story, characters and lore all tie in with the main series and this is a rich addition to the world of Deus Ex as far as narrative is concerned, so from the get-go many characters already seen in other games are more likeable. The locations in Panama are very interesting, and is a nice refresher from the locations from Human Revolution. The music is mostly borrowed from Human Revolution, so it is very nice. All characters that have appeared in other games are still using the same voice actors and most main characters have solid performances, but are limited by the engine. If you enjoyed the weapons from Human Revolution, most are in the game and new variations are presented in the game, with different stats and skins, the Belltower Shotgun is my favorite, being fully automatic with a press of the trigger. A new augmentation, the stealth dash, is fun and serves as a balancing measure since the Typhoon is still experimental. There is a good replay value with the New Game +, and the economy of the game presents a challenge for those seeking to get all items or augmentations.Bottom line: The game deserves a better treatment. If the story was to be all finsihed up, and was given the AAA treatment, with big city hubs and more sidequests, nicer, updated graphics and better AI, I am sure it would become a fan favorite. There is potential, and it is a shame to see it wasted in a mobile version ported to PC. But the game is good in it's core, only limited by the parameters of a mobile game. If you are interested in the Deus Ex universe, this is a nice side story with more to be told. Give it a shot.

content:
Posted: April 24
												So the general consensus about this is game, is that its terrible. Well, I don't agree with this. I think it's a pretty decent Deus Ex game, keeping in mind this was made for mobile phones. Of course the graphics aren't as good (they aren't bad though, and it runs quite smoothly), the controls are a little iffy (they are made with controllers in mind, so maybe get one of those), the story a little less deep (the cliffhanger ending is so bad, really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that they didn't develop anything else after this) and the overal package just, less. But for the low pricepoint (I got it on sale for 2,49) you can buy much worse. I wouldn't recommend this to newcomers, as this is one of the worst points to start with Deus Ex. But to seasoned Deus Ex players (or people who really ♥♥♥♥ing loved Deus Ex: Human Revolution aka me) this is a really fun little experience with some nice backstory to add to the Deus Ex lore. Oh yeah, the music is also ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. (some tracks are recycled from DE:HR, but there are a couple of new tracks that are really good!)
